misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Sorting one parallel array automatically keeps the other array aligned
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if they sort the scores array, the corresponding names in the separate names array will still match those scores by index (i.e., the “pairing” between name and score is preserved automatically).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays have no built-in relationship to each other. `Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray)` only reorders elements inside `studentScoresArray`. It does not know anything about `studentNamesArray`, so the indices no longer represent the same student-name/score pair after sorting unless you also reorder the names in the same way (or sort a combined structure).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the printed top student name may not be the one who actually earned the top score (the score printed will be the max score, but the name will just be whoever was originally last in the input).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when they sort one array (scores), the corresponding elements in the parallel array (names) will automatically rearrange themselves to stay synchronized. They think that sorting the scores array will magically keep the names aligned with their original scores.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, Arrays.sort() only modifies the array it operates on. It does not know about or modify other arrays. When you sort `studentScoresArray`, the `studentNamesArray` remains completely unchanged. The student has confused the logical relationship between parallel arrays (they represent paired data) with the actual implementation reality (they are independent data structures). After sorting scores in ascending order, the name at index `numberOfStudents - 1` is no longer necessarily paired with the highest score.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: The program will produce incorrect output. For the sample input (Alice/85, Bob/92, Charlie/78), after sorting scores to [78, 85, 92], the names array is still [Alice, Bob, Charlie]. The program prints the name at the last index (Charlie) with the highest score (92), producing 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of the correct 'Top student: Bob (92)'.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because the studentNamesArray and studentScoresArray were populated using the same indices, they are intrinsically linked by the JVM. Therefore, sorting the scores array will automatically reorder the names array to maintain the correct pairings.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects. The concept of 'parallel arrays' is a logical abstraction created by the programmer, not a feature of the language. The Java Runtime Environment has no knowledge of the semantic relationship between elements at the same index in different arrays. Calling Arrays.sort() on one array modifies its contents in-place without affecting the memory or ordering of any other array, effectively 'de-syncing' the names from their original scores.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel Arrays Stay Synchronized Automatically After Sorting One Array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if they sort the scores array, the corresponding student names will still line up with those scores at the same indices (so the last name in the names array will be the student who earned the last/highest score in the sorted scores array).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray)` only rearranges the elements *inside that one array*. It does not know that `studentNamesArray` is “paired” with it, so it will not perform the same swaps in the names array. After sorting just the scores, the index positions no longer represent the same students across the two arrays. To keep parallel arrays aligned, you must move/swap elements in both arrays together whenever you reorder by score (or use an array of objects / index-sorting).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output (prints a name that may not actually have the highest score, even though it prints the highest score correctly).

evidence.code_snippet: // Step 9: After sorting in ascending order, the top student is at the last index

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when they sort the `studentScoresArray` using `Arrays.sort()`, the `studentNamesArray` will somehow automatically reorder itself to stay matched with the scores. They think the computer understands that these are 'paired' arrays and will keep them synchronized during sorting.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort()` only modifies the specific array passed to it. It does not understand semantic relationships between separate arrays. The `studentNamesArray` remains completely unchanged when `studentScoresArray` is sorted. This breaks the correspondence between names and scores. After sorting only the scores array, accessing `studentNamesArray[numberOfStudents - 1]` no longer retrieves the name of the student with the highest score.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output. With the sample input (Alice 85, Bob 92, Charlie 78), the program will output 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of the correct 'Top student: Bob (92)'. The score is correct, but the name is wrong.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because the names and scores were entered into two arrays at the same indices, the computer 'understands' they are paired entities. Therefore, they believe sorting the scores array will automatically rearrange the names array to maintain those pairs.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, parallel arrays have no intrinsic logical connection. Arrays.sort() is an operation that only affects the specific memory addresses of the array it is called upon. It does not track or update indices of other arrays that the programmer might consider 'related'.
